dt: {bc}to share or reveal too much information

dt.t: Shakarian cautions students to not {wi}overshare{/wi} information online, to create complex passwords and to only use secure networks.
The sharing and discussion of emotion has always been heavily gendered and women who "{wi}overshare{/wi}" details of their private lives have historically been maligned.

… [Rihanna] doesn't {wi}overshare{/wi} her life on social media—despite having 60 million and 86 million followers on Instagram and Twitter respectively—and you never know who she's dating, despite who you see her with.

In an exclusive Parents survey of more than 2,000 respondents, 79 percent said other parents {wi}overshare{/wi} on social media – yet only 32 percent of us think we overshare ourselves … Of course, what's {d_link|TMI|TMI} in one parent's eyes may be just fine in another's.
It used to be rare for C.I.A. employees to recount their exploits, or grievances, in print. Now, they're {wi}oversharing{/wi} as eagerly as the cast of "Jersey Shore."

utxt.t: In this age of social media, it's kind of hard not to be an {wi}oversharer{/wi}.
Fortunately, librarians are the original {wi}oversharers{/wi}, and they've produced a body of literature—from blog posts to articles to books—to help you with your decision.

shortdef: to share or reveal too much information
